entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 31 at 12:24PM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
At 1224 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 10 miles north of Patroon, or 15 miles east of Center, moving east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Many, Zwolle, Converse, Patroon, Oak Grove, Pleasant Hill, Huxley, Noble, Toledo Bend Reservoir North, Pelican, Belmont, Jordans Store and Hurstown.
entry.cap:areaDesc: De Soto; Sabine; Shelby; Sabine

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued October 31 at 12:00PM CDT until October 31 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast Texas, including the following counties, Brazoria, Galveston and Harris.
* WHEN...Until 100 PM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At noon CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Southern Pasadena, southeastern Pearland, League City, Texas City, Friendswood, Alvin, Dickinson, Santa Fe, southern Seabrook, Webster, Hitchcock, Kemah, southern Clear Lake, Nassau Bay, Taylor Lake Village, El Lago, Clear Lake Shores, Hillcrest, Liverpool and The Johnson Space Center. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 9:55AM PDT until November 2 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected above 6,000 feet. Total snow accumulations up to 5-7 inches expected, with 8 inches possible at the highest elevations. At Tioga Pass, there is a 59 percent chance of four or more inches of snow, and a 26 percent chance of six inches or more of snow.
* WHERE...Kaiser to Rodgers Ridge, Kings Canyon NP, Upper San Joaquin River, and Yosemite NP outside of the valley.
* WHEN...From 5 PM Friday to 11 PM PDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday evening commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yosemite NP outside of the valley; Upper San Joaquin River; Kaiser to Rodgers Ridge; Kings Canyon NP

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 11:47AM CDT until October 31 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
entry.summary:
...WET HEAVY SNOW TO CONTINUE INTO THIS AFTERNOON WITH TRAVEL IMPACTS LIKELY...
.As colder air continues to move in from the northwest, precipitation will change over to heavy snow from west to east with snowfall rates of an inch per hour at times into early afternoon. A few embedded thunderstorms are also possible, which could enhance snow rates further. Total accumulations of 2 to 4 inches are likely in a narrow band from around the New Ulm area through western and northern portions the Twin Cities metro area, to northwest Wisconsin. Locally higher totals are possible if the heaviest bands remain nearly stationary. In addition, northwest winds 15 to 20 mph with gusts as high as 30 or 35 mph could aid in deteriorating travel conditions.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 4 inches. Locally higher totals are possible.
* WHERE...McLeod, Meeker, Renville, Sherburne, Sibley, Wright, Carver, and Isanti Counties.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM CDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sherburne; Isanti; Meeker; Wright; Renville; McLeod; Sibley; Carver

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 31 at 11:10AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Above Lake Harney affecting Seminole County.
.The Saint Johns River Above Lake Harney near Geneva has fallen to Minor Flood Stage and will continue a steady decline over the next week. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River near Lake Harney will continue to experience prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Above Lake Harney...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued late tonight at midnight EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Above Lake Harney.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.8 feet, Water covers Whitcomb Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Thursday was 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 8.8 feet. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Seminole, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 31 at 11:07AM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.On the St Johns River at Astor, breezy onshore winds have slowed the rate of declining water levels, but a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage over the next week remains forecast. Residents and interests along the Saint Johns River should continue to expect prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued late tonight at 1245 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.5 feet, Canals have overflowed into yards. Homes on or near Wildhog, Bonnet and Snail roads become inaccessible with several inches of water inside homes along the river and canals. Docks at Astor Bridge marina and throughout Astor are completely submerged. Bartram Rd and Holiday Circle are inaccessible with yards completely submerged. Clair Street is inaccessible. Roads flooded in South Moon Fish Camp, docks and yards at condominiums on Juno Trail and water breaches the sea wall at Blair's Jungle Den.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 3.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:30 AM EDT Thursday was 3.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 3.5 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Watch issued October 31 at 10:34AM AST until November 2 at 8:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands.
* WHEN...Through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff will result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams will rise out of their banks, particularly across eastern Puerto Rico. Flooding will occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Favorable atmospheric conditions for shower and thunderstorm development will continue to prevail across the forecast area. Soils are already saturated, particularly across eastern portions of Puerto Rico; therefore any prolonged period of heavy rainfall will result in rapid rises along small streams and rivers as well as flooding in poor drainage and urban areas. Rainfall totals, thru at least Saturday morning, are expected to range from 3 to 6 inches, with locally higher amounts of 8 to 10 inches across northern and eastern Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Elsewhere, expect rainfall amounts around 1 to 2 inches. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; Southeast; Eastern Interior; North Central; Central Interior; Ponce and Vicinity; Northwest; Western Interior; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Southwest; Culebra; Vieques; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands; St Croix

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING

This will primarily affect communities south of Egegik, including Pilot Point and Port Heiden. Areas north of Egegik will see lighter east to northeasterly winds, with gusts to about 45 mph.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 4:41AM AKDT until November 1 at 4:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches and ice accumulations of up to one tenth of an inch.
* WHERE...Western Kenai Peninsula.
* WHEN...From 4 AM Thursday to 4 AM AKDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Light snow will develop Thursday morning. Warmer air aloft moving over the region is expected to change the snow to a wintry mix of snow and freezing rain sometime around noon Thursday. The wintry mix may then change back to all snow by late Thursday evening before tapering off early Friday morning. This is a complex setup. The amount of snow and ice accumulation will be dependent the extent of warm air aloft. Higher snow totals and less ice accumulation are likely if colder air remains in place over the region. The highest snow amounts are expected from Nikiski south to Ninilchik. Higher ice accumulation are expected east of Kenai, including Soldotna and Sterling.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 3:50AM PDT until October 31 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow for elevations above 6000 feet. Additional snow accumulations of 2-4 inches, locally higher at peaks and higher elevations. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County, West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada, and Western Plumas County/Lassen Park Counties.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM PDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Snow covered roads, chain controls and travel delays possible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snowfall is expected through Thursday afternoon, then scattered snow showers will persist. entry.summary:
...EARLY SEASON SNOWFALL TO THE CASCADES THROUGH FRIDAY AFTERNOON...
.A cold front will bring a rapid onset of accumulating snow above 4000 feet this afternoon and evening. Precipitation will be more showery today, increasing in intensity tonight into Friday. Highest accumulations will be above 5000 feet and in the Linn and Lane County Cascades. Winds too will become gusty from the south tonight which will increase chances for blowing snow and reduced visibility.

* WHEN...Until 5 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes.
